{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3256651,"name":"lobrien","username":"lobrien","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/lobrien/{size}/11768_2.png","created_at":"2023-11-23T18:15:54.614Z","cooked":"

I’ve been using Docker to create a low-friction development environment for exploring computer vision and machine learning in Python. For that, I have an image to which they can attach from Visual Studio Code and also gives them a Jupyter Web server (interactive notebook interface for Python, which makes for easy graphics, plots, and interactive lessons). If anyone’s already done an image for wpilib, I’d appreciate a link. If I figure it out, I’ll make the Dockerfile available. If anyone’s got a similar project, perhaps we could cooperate?

I spent some time yesterday trying to add wpilib to my base image but had some trouble. Is anyone else going this route or wants to warn against the effort?

My image is Ubuntu 22.04 without a graphical shell / desktop. I tried to install wpilib from the Linux installer, but AFAICT there’s no command-line -y or somesuch that bypasses the GUI.

So I thought I’d clone the repo and build it. This goes well but the build uses -Werror (impressive!) which treats warnings as errors. The build stops on a “deprecated enum-enum conversion” warning (I can get the exact warning if it helps). Perhaps I need a specific version of gcc/gcpp?

I’m not very familiar with gradle so I’m not confident how to pass a -Wno-error argument through to the compiler. Instead, I grepped for the warning and the only place it showed up was in a compiler flags file inside a conditional that “made sense” (it checked if the build was on UNIX but not APPLE: yes, that is true). As an experiment I tried to comment that conditional out but the build has the same failure.

There are a number of images available from the wpilib organization, but AFAICT these are for development. Perhaps the smartest route forward is to use one of these to build wpilib libraries and then to layer Python stuff on top?

tl;dr: I am interested in building a Docker dev environment for wpilib (ultimately for use with Python). The installer seems to rely on X, which is unavailable. Building the library stumped me with a warning-treated-as-an-error. Looking for help and/or collaborators (or “For heaven’s sake, don’t do it!” experiences).

lobrien:

The build stops on a “deprecated enum-enum conversion” warning

We suppress some warnings; that’s one of them: native-utils/src/main/java/edu/wpi/first/nativeutils/WPINativeUtilsExtension.java at main · wpilibsuite/native-utils · GitHub

If your goal is to use WPILib functionality from Python, it would be much easier to use the RobotPy packages than building everything yourself from source.

Does the robotpy install on Linux install the wpilib library dependencies with just pip or conda and no GUI interaction? Once I have the C/C++ wpilib libs in place, I’m definitely planning on layering robotpy over it in the image.

lobrien:

Does the robotpy install on Linux install the wpilib library dependencies with just pip or conda and no GUI interaction?

Yes. But they’re installed for use by Python; the native libraries RobotPy installs are not designed to be used directly from C++.

github.com

TheTripleV/robotpy-gitpod-test/blob/main/.gitpod.Dockerfile

FROM gitpod/workspace-full-vnc
RUN sudo apt-get update && \
    sudo apt-get install -y libgtk-3-dev && \
    sudo rm -rf /var/lib/apt/lists/*

USER gitpod
RUN pyenv install 3.9.1
RUN pyenv global 3.9.1
RUN pyenv rehash

# ENV PYTHONUSERBASE=/workspace/.pip-modules
# RUN pyenv init

RUN pip install --upgrade pip
RUN pip install --upgrade wheel setuptools
RUN pip install --upgrade pylint rich python-language-server[all]
# I forgot to publish navx to pypi
RUN pip install --upgrade robotpy[navx] --find-links https://www.tortall.net/~robotpy/wheels/2021/linux_x86_64/
RUN pip install --upgrade robotpy[all]

Well, our team wants to use Python (unless they spring a BIG surprise on me come January!), so that’s not an issue.

/me rushes downstairs

Had to switch root distros from Debian to Ubuntu, but this works:

Dockerfile for FIRST Robotics with PyTorch, robotpy and Jupyter Server (github.com)

You can’t wpilib.run(MyRobot) in Jupyter, but if you connect to the container using VS Code (or just open a terminal), you can do so.

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":16,"updated_at":"2023-11-23T21:19:01.317Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":6,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":158,"readers_count":157,"score":36.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":444765,"topic_slug":"docker-dev-environment-for-24-season","display_username":"lobrien","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://gist.github.com/lobrien/ad9bf8bf3fabda844b88523550f54985","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"Dockerfile for FIRST Robotics with PyTorch, robotpy and Jupyter Server · GitHub","clicks":6}],"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":13575,"username":"Peter_Johnson","name":"Peter Johnson","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/peter_johnson/{size}/10417_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":27030,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/docker-dev-environment-for-24-season/444765/8","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3256718,"name":"Dustin Spicuzza","username":"virtuald","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/virtuald/{size}/65268_2.png","created_at":"2023-11-24T00:32:12.560Z","cooked":"
Peter_Johnson:

Yes. But they’re installed for use by Python; the native libraries RobotPy installs are not designed to be used directly from C++.

Strictly speaking, everything you need to use them from C++ is there if you set up your include paths and library paths correctly, but you really don’t want to do that.

lobrien:

You can’t wpilib.run(MyRobot) in Jupyter, but if you connect to the container using VS Code (or just open a terminal), you can do so.

Even if it did work, it wouldn’t be very useful since wpilib.run isn’t intended to ever return.

I don’t use jupyter at all, my perception is that it’s very useful for certain kinds of discrete computational tasks, but not really useful for a continuous system like a robot. I am curious what sorts of things you might find useful to use jupyter + robot code for. If you had some compelling ideas we might be able to add stuff to robotpy/wpilib to enhance the support for doing some of this.

","post_number":9,"post_type":1,"posts_count":16,"updated_at":"2023-11-24T00:32:12.560Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":8,"quote_count":2,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":128,"readers_count":127,"score":35.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":444765,"topic_slug":"docker-dev-environment-for-24-season","display_username":"Dustin Spicuzza","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":11063,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"RobotPy Guy, WPILib Developer"},"post_url":"/t/docker-dev-environment-for-24-season/444765/9","custom_user_title":"RobotPy Guy, WPILib Developer","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3256719,"name":"","username":"Vasista","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/v/ccd318/{size}.png","created_at":"2023-11-24T00:56:51.336Z","cooked":"
virtuald:

not really useful for a continuous system like a robot

It’s actually very useful for prototyping and doing things like changing setpoints and pid constants on the fly.

Though for robot code, you’d need a custom jupyter kernel that connects to an already running robot and blocks at the jupyter cell execution level. So I’ve always used hackier solutions than ever trying to do it properly.

","post_number":10,"post_type":1,"posts_count":16,"updated_at":"2023-11-24T00:57:23.866Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":9,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":110,"readers_count":109,"score":22.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":444765,"topic_slug":"docker-dev-environment-for-24-season","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":39370,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"5940 | 4096 | WPILib and Robotpy Developer"},"post_url":"/t/docker-dev-environment-for-24-season/444765/10","custom_user_title":"5940 | 4096 | WPILib and Robotpy Developer","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3256909,"name":"lobrien","username":"lobrien","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/lobrien/{size}/11768_2.png","created_at":"2023-11-25T00:40:05.870Z","cooked":"

I am curious what sorts of things you might find useful to use jupyter + robot code for

I’m not at all sure, especially reading @Vasista 's “custom kernel that connects …” etc., which seems like real work. My initial thought was test code and, as you say, discrete tasks. My real hope is simply that Docker is a good route to have new team-members get to a running “helloworld_robot.py” as quickly as possible. If that were to happen via Jupyter, that’d have been awesome, but if it happens by attaching VS Code and opening a terminal, that’s still quicker than setting up a complete dev laptop.

I use Jupyter with the team for other stuff: graphing, machine learning, computer vision, etc. If Docker’s a good fit for FRC development, I would prefer to just give them a single Docker container that can do both subjects (ML and FRC).

(But maybe Docker isn’t a good fit for FRC? I would imagine that deploying to the RoboRio from an image is a significant hassle? So maybe all the serious team members will need the FRC stack on their primary OS? I’d love to hear experiences.)

","post_number":11,"post_type":1,"posts_count":16,"updated_at":"2023-11-25T00:42:27.040Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":9,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":85,"readers_count":84,"score":22.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":444765,"topic_slug":"docker-dev-environment-for-24-season","display_username":"lobrien","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":11063,"username":"virtuald","name":"Dustin Spicuzza","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/virtuald/{size}/65268_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":27030,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/docker-dev-environment-for-24-season/444765/11","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3256935,"name":"Chris Gerth","username":"gerthworm","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/gerthworm/{size}/268658_2.png","created_at":"2023-11-25T01:38:21.674Z","cooked":"

Fwiw we put together a training kernel that took code snippets and ran them inside a bonafide robot project. Still not convinced it’s completely useful, but at least one sample point…

lobrien:

I would imagine that deploying to the RoboRio from an image is a significant hassle?

If your docker container can talk to the network and if it has robotpy-installer in it, and your robot is at a static IP address**, then deploy should Just Work.

** I don’t know how well mDNS lookups would work from inside a docker container, but I’m guessing it would be really annoying to get it to work correctly

gerthworm:

pythonTraining/TrainingKernel at main · RobotCasserole1736/pythonTraining · GitHub

FWIW, if anyone is interested in doing some deeper jupyter integration, RobotPy/wpilib has a bunch of hooks in simulation to allow controlling the robot for unit test purposes, so conceivably they could be leveraged or adapted for jupyter integration. See pyfrc/pyfrc/test_support at main · robotpy/pyfrc · GitHub

WRT to running jupyter on the robot and debugging a live robot program… that sounds pretty neat honestly. I remember creating a custom jupyter kernel a long time ago for something for work, and it wasn’t that hard.

Neat. Yeah, we’ve been using GitHub - TheTripleV/robotpy-remoterepl: Access a REPL that runs within your robot code . But it’s a bit tedious to run 2 or 3 commands over and over again in the terminal. Jupyter has better ux for that so I’d prefer it
